awd_titl_txt: MPS-Ascend: From Directly Imaged Planets to Directly Characterized Planets: A Multi-pronged Approach to Understand Planet Formation Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  Raquel Martinez is awarded a NSF Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (NSF MPS-Ascend) to conduct a program of research and activities related to broaden participation by groups underrepresented in STEM. This fellowship to Dr. Martinez supports her research project entitled "MPS-Ascend: From Directly Imaged Planets to Directly Characterized Planets: A Multi-pronged Approach to Understand Planet Formation Processes", under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The host institution for the fellowship the University of California, Irvine (UCI), and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Steph Sallum. 

This proposal will advance understanding of the origin, evolution, and demographics of gas giant exoplanets and wide-orbit planetary-mass companions (PMCs). Current theories of planet and star formation are unable to explain the observed characteristics of PMCs largely because of inadequate statistics. The proposer will reveal the dominant formation pathways of PMCs by efficiently building the wide-orbit planetary-mass and substellar companion sample, then pursuing detailed observational followup of new and known wide companion discoveries. The PI will also be a member of the SCALES (Santa Cruz Array of Lenslets for Exoplanet Spectroscopy) instrument team. SCALES is a mid-infrared high-contrast integral-field spectrograph designed to detect and characterize exoplanets.

Martinez will organize weekly seminars and implement a near-peer mentorship program for the Summer Undergraduate Research Opportunities Fellowship (SURF) and Cal-Bridge/CAMPARE programs at UCI. She will also mentor a SURF or CAMPARE student in a research project related to the proposed work each summer during the MPS-Ascend Fellowship. The educational activities will reach 5-10 undergraduate summer researchers each year.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF MPS Ascending Postdoctoral Fellowship (Award 2213312) was a two-year, $200,000 grant that funded Dr. Raquel A. Martinez. Under the supervision of sponsoring scientist Dr. Steph Sallum at the University of California, Irvine, the major goals of  this award were to use state-of-the-art facilities, novel observing strategies, and custom-built image processing algorithms to further our understanding of how exoplanets (planets that orbit stars outside our solar system) form and evolve, while also expanding the exoplanet characterization parameter space.

Major Outcomes:

Over the course of the award, Dr. Martinez led two observing runs to characterize 5 wide-orbit planetary-mass companions and isolated brown dwarfs to understand how fast they were forming and calibrate accretion signatures present at infrared wavelengths to any detected excess ultraviolet (UV) radiation. One of the target systems, FU Tau A and B, revealed hydrogen emission lines in the near-infrared in the 50 Jupiter mass primary (FU Tau A), and evidence of UV emission in the planetary-mass companion (FU Tau B)—indications of ongoing accretion that has not been detected in objects of such low-mass before. A manuscript of the FU observations is in progress with anticipated submission for review and publication in 2025.

Dr. Martinez and colleagues have collaborated to utilize her IRAC image-processing pipeline to reinvestigate interesting young stars and white dwarfs with suspected wide-orbit planetary mass companions. A manuscript of that work is on track to be submitted for review in the first half of 2025.

As a member of the instrument and science team for SCALES, Dr. Martinez developed the computational infrastructure to easily incorporate accreting protoplant spectral energy distributions and variable sky conditions into SCALES’ observation simulation software in anticipation of community needs for observation planning during SCALES commissioning and beyond. Dr. Martinez also performed initial investigations into higher-resolution planetary-accretion observing modes for a future upgrade of SCALES, determining that an increase of resolving power by a factor of 2-3 could significantly improve SCALES’ ability to constrain accretion in forming gas giant exoplanets. These findings resulted in SPIE Optics + Photonics proceedings.

Broader Impacts:

Dr. Martinez joined the instructional staff of the Institute for Scientist and Engineering Educators (ISEE) Professional Development Program (PDP), an in-depth pedagogical experience for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars that teaches them about backwards design and inquiry-based learning, guiding participants to develop an authentic, inclusive, STEM learning experience (AISLE) for undergraduate physics and astronomy students. In addition to leading pedagogical activities that enabled PDP participants to personally experience an AISLE themselves, Dr. Martinez was a member of the professional development team that guided participants through sessions about effective leadership and teamwork. They also served as a participant to develop an AISLE for AstroTech.

Dr. Martinez joined the instructional staff of AstroTech, an astronomical instrumentation summer school for ~30 undergraduates and early graduate students interested in a career in instrumentation. AstroTech is an initiative to make the field of astronomical instrumentation more inclusive and as part of its instructional staff, Dr. Martinez helped participants gain hands-on experience working in small teams to build a spectrograph with an equity-minded approach, while also providing additional professional development to AstroTech participants, as well as instructors and facilitators in inclusive teamwork. Dr. Martinez is also mentor and resource for AstroTech participants as they continue their pursuit of astronomy careers after the program has ended.
